0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Dental surgical procedure - Hemophilia - Hemorrhage; Treatment and Prophylaxis: IV or ORAL, 75 mg/kg (up to 6 g) immediately following surgery, then every 6 hr for 7-10 days
  • Dental surgical procedure - Hemophilia - Hemorrhage; Treatment and Prophylaxis: Oral rinse, 5 mL (1.25 g) swished for 30 seconds 4 times a day for 7-10 days; small quantities may be swallowed (except when used during the first and second trimesters of pregnancy)
  • Hematuria, Surgical, non-surgical: initial 4-5 gm IV, diluted in 250 mL of D5W or NS, infuse over 1 hr, followed by 1 g/hr (50 mL/hr) for about 8 hr or until bleeding is controlled
  • Hematuria, Surgical, non-surgical: initial 5 g ORALLY during the first hr, followed by 1 g/hr ORALLY for 8 hr or until bleeding is controlled
  • Hemorrhage - Increased fibrinolysis: initial 4-5 gm IV, diluted in 250 mL of D5W or NS, infuse over 1 hr, followed by 1 g/hr (50 mL/hr) for about 8 hr or until bleeding is controlled
  • Hemorrhage - Increased fibrinolysis: initial 5 g ORALLY during the first hr, followed by 1 g/hr ORALLY for 8 hr or until bleeding is controlled
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage, Recurrence: IV or ORAL, 36 g/day (18 g in 400 mL of D5W infused over each 12-hr period) for 10 days. Therapy is continued using orally administered aminocaproic acid

2.title: Dose Adjustments
2.mono: renal impairment: reduce dose to 15 to 25% of normal doses in patients with renal disease or oliguria

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Hematuria, Surgical, non-surgical
  • Hemorrhage - Increased fibrinolysis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Dental surgical procedure - Hemophilia - Hemorrhage; Treatment and Prophylaxis
  • Intraocular hemorrhage
  • Postoperative hemorrhage; Prophylaxis
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage, Recurrence

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cerebral ischemia has occurred in patients treated for subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • cerebral vasospasm has occurred in patients treated for subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • concomitant use with factor IX complex concentrates or anti-inhibitor coagulant concentrate should be avoided
  • hydrocephalus has occurred in patients treated for subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • necrosis of heart and liver tissue has occurred in cases where skeletal myopathy is present
  • prolonged administration; risk of skeletal muscle weakness, necrosis of muscle fibers and rhabdomyolysis; monitoring recommended; discontinuation necessary
  • upper urinary tract bleeding; increased risk of intrarenal obstruction or glomerular capillary thrombosis; use alternative therapy in patients with hematuria of upper urinary tract origin or use with caution if the benefit of therapy outweighs the risk

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Myocardial necrosis
  • Hematologic:Hemorrhage, Thrombosis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Musculoskeletal:Muscle necrosis, Proximal myopathy, Severe, Rhabdomyolysis
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident, Intracranial hypertension, acute, Seizure
  • Renal:Myoglobinuria, Renal failure, Urinary tract obstruction
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Aminocaproic acid competitively inhibits activation of plasminogen , thereby reducing conversion of plasminogen to plasmin (fibrinolysin), an enzyme that degrades fibrin clots as well as fibrinogen and other plasma proteins including the procoagulant factors V and VIII . Aminocaproic acid also directly inhibits plasmin activity, but higher doses are required than are needed to reduce plasmin formation . In vitro, the antifibrinolytic potency of aminocaproic acid is approximately one-fifth to one-tenth that of tranexamic acid .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • (infusion) dilute with NS, D5W, or LR; Sterile Water for Injection may also be used but will produce hypo-osmolar solution
  • rapid administration of undiluted injection into a vein is not recommended

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• initial confirmed diagnosis of primary fibrinolysis prior to administration
  • CBC, DIC panel, and coagulation panel initially and after treatment
  • muscle enzymes, especially CPK with long term use; rhabdomyolysis, myositis, myalgia, muscle weakness
  • bradycardia, hypotension, peripheral ischemia, thrombosis
  • dyspnea, pulmonary embolism
  • BUN, renal failure

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Intravenous Solution: 250 MG/ML
    • Oral Solution: 1.25 GM/5 ML
    • Oral Tablet: 500 MG, 1000 MG
  • Amicar
    Oral Tablet: 500 MG
  • Novaplus Aminocaproic Acid
    Intravenous Solution: 250 MG/ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness.
  • This drug may cause nausea, vomiting, asthenia, headache, or drug-induced myopathy.
  • Tell patient to report bradyarrhythmia or hypotension.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of rhabdomyolysis (myalgias, dark urine, arthralgias, fatigue), thrombotic disorder, peripheral ischemia, or renal failure.
  • Advise patient to call healthcare professional if a dose is missed, as drug should be given on a regular schedule.
